lesson.title: Addition and Subtraction Practice
objectives: Strengthen number sense through addition and subtraction
Enhance problem-solving skills with word problems
lesson.overview: This lesson will help students in grades 2 and 3 practice their addition and subtraction skills with a focus on number sense and problem solving.

introduction.description: Introduce the concepts of addition and subtraction, emphasizing number sense and problem-solving strategies.
instructions: Explain the importance of lining up numbers by place value in addition and subtraction.
Discuss strategies for solving word problems, such as underlining key information.

activity.description: Students will complete a set of addition and subtraction problems to practice their computation and problem-solving skills.
instructions: Complete the worksheet problems by showing your work for each computation problem.
Read each word problem carefully and apply problem-solving strategies discussed.

teacherIntroduction.script: Today, we're going to practice addition and subtraction. Remember to line up your numbers by place value and read each word problem carefully to understand what is being asked.

whiteboardExamples.title: Example 1: Addition
steps: Line up 23 and 19 by place value.
Add the units: 3 + 9 = 12. Write down 2 and carry over 1.
whiteboardExamples.teachingPoint: Emphasize carrying over when the sum of a column is 10 or more.

whiteboardExamples.title: Example 2: Subtraction
steps: Line up 54 and 27 by place value.
Subtract the units: 4 - 7. Since 4 is smaller, borrow 1 from the tens place.
whiteboardExamples.teachingPoint: Highlight the importance of borrowing when the top number is smaller.

whiteboardExamples.title: Example 3: Word Problem
whiteboardExamples.problem: If you have 10 apples and give away 4, how many do you have left?
steps: Identify what is being asked: How many apples are left?
Subtract the number of apples given away from the total.
whiteboardExamples.teachingPoint: Encourage students to identify keywords and use subtraction to find the solution.

problems.question: If you have 5 candies and get 3 more, how many do you have?
If you have 18 oranges and eat 4, how many do you have left?
If you have 5 candies and get 3 more, how many do you have?
If you have 18 oranges and eat 4, how many do you have left?
If you have 20 pencils and give away 6, how many do you have left?
If you collect 50 stamps and lose 8, how many do you have?
